thread.title: How Trump can take down ObamaCare without leaving millions uninsured | New York Post
thread.title_full: How Trump can take down ObamaCare without leaving millions uninsured | New York Post

author: Carl Campanile
title: How Trump can take down ObamaCare without leaving millions uninsured | New York Post
text:
A total repeal of ObamaCare will prove difficult — but there’s plenty Donald Trump and his fellow Republicans can do to effectively dismantle President Obama’s signature domestic program. 
Trump could exempt more people from the individual mandate to buy insurance, and his administration could stop assisting consumers with enrollment.
If the government stops fighting a lawsuit that’s trying to put an end to subsidies for low-income people’s bills, insurers’ costs would go up, and they could choose to drop out of the markets. 
“Without an administration committed to the program, more [insurers] will almost certainly withdraw, potentially leaving parts of the country where no marketplace plans are available,” Timothy Jost, a Washington and Lee University School of Law professor, wrote in a blog post on the Health Affairs Web site.
“Others might raise their rates in the face of the uncertainty caused by the transition, making coverage even less affordable.”
Trump confidant Roger Stone said the president-elect will follow through on his pledge to replace ObamaCare. 
“It’s not easy. But Donald says what he means and means what he says,” Stone told The Post. 
“They have to have an alternative that’s market-based. It can be done. Look, the ObamaCare exchanges have crashed. The insurers are pulling out,” the longtime Trump adviser said. 
HealthGrove | Graphiq But he also insisted Trump won’t leave people in the lurch, including millions of low-income Americans who qualified for Medicaid through ObamaCare. 
“Donald has said repeatedly he won’t put people out on the street without medical coverage,” Stone said.
Jonathan Gruber, the MIT professor who helped design the Affordable Care Act, said Trump is playing with fire.
“If you repeal the Affordable Care Act, you’re taking away coverage from millions of people. I have not seen an alternative. There isn’t one,” Gruber told The Post.
Repealing the law would allow insurers to discriminate against sick people, since it currently bars them from denying coverage to those with pre-existing conditions, he said.
The ACA “has been a big success in New York state. We don’t want to go backwards,” said David Sandman, president of the New York State Health Foundation.
“It’s not easy taking the law apart . . . Finding a way to retain medical coverage for 22 million is a problem.”
